clinical_study.brief_title: Arthrocentesis and Temporomandibular Joint Disorders a Conservative Alternative to Surgical Treatments

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to evaluate the efficacy of arthrocentesis in the treatment of internal derangement of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

detailed_description.textblock: This work was designed as a prospective case series clinical study. Patients imaging was evaluated with Cone-Beam Computed Tomography and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance at the beginning of the treatment and after the last arthrocentesis.

primary_outcome.time_frame: baseline (preop), 1 week, 1 month, 2 months, 6 months, 12 months (postop)
primary_outcome.description: Patients were followed up for 1 year. The mean pre-operative pain, using visual analog scale, showed an average decrease of 6.7 at 1 year.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (preop), 1 week, 1 month, 2 months, 6 months, 12 months (postop)
primary_outcome.description: The mean maximum mouth opening(MMO) pre-operatively was 15,8 mm and increased to 34 mm immediately following arthrocentesis which increased by 0.5-1 mm at every month followup with mean MMO of 39,4 mm at 6 months. Thereafter it remained consistent till 1 year. The mean increase in the mouth opening at 1 year was 23,6 mm
At the end of 1 year, (75%) patients stated no evidence of clicking.

secondary_outcome.measure: number of subjects showing signs of TMJ inflammation or structural alterations at Magnetic Resonance Imaging and Cone Beam Computerized Tomography pre- and postop.
secondary_outcome.description: 40% of subjects who showed clear signs of inflammation showed significant improvement, in 30% with structural alterations was evident the absence of intra-articular adhesions and debris, in 30% with internal derangement did not appear any radiographic change.

arm_group.description: 30 patients with TMJ internal derangement and pain with history of failed conservative management.

intervention.description: lavage of the superior TMJ space with saline and sodium hyaluronate (SH)

study_pop.textblock: A total of 30 patients with TMJ internal derangement and pain with history of failed conservative management were selected. 70% had anteriorly displaced discs (AD), and 30 complained of other disorders (osteophytes, signs of soft tissues inflammmation, TMJ structure alterations).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- TMJ pain
- TMJ noises and click
- history of unsuccessful conservative management (NSAID and occlusal bite)
- occlusal bite still present
Exclusion Criteria:
- degenerative joint disease (such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis etc.)
- history of condylar fractures or previous TMJ trauma
- TMJ surgery
